crossref_summary: Transcript evidence strongly confirms that the biggest Layer 1 disappointments are not theoretical: users repeatedly describe trust uncertainty, manual verification labor, and off-platform coordination exactly at high-risk moments. Hosts and guests both rely on ad hoc workarounds (texts, screenshots, external calendars, manual vet checks, personal legitimacy proofs), which mirrors the Roomster pattern of strong lead flow but weak end-to-end decision and commitment infrastructure. The calls also reveal two grounded extensions: a recurring legitimacy-proof burden before users trust the channel at all, and rescheduling failures caused by hidden cross-platform availability constraints.

new_discoveries.title: Legitimacy Proof Tax Before Any Real Booking Conversation

transcript_evidence.speaker: host
transcript_evidence.quote: I don't know if this guy is legit or what it is.
transcript_evidence.context: User blocks progress until identity is proven.

transcript_evidence.speaker: host
transcript_evidence.quote: there are so many scams around and I've already been scammed twice.
transcript_evidence.context: Prior scam experience creates a default skepticism posture.

transcript_evidence.speaker: guest
transcript_evidence.quote: I have to go and see the space and just to make sure that everything is legit.
transcript_evidence.context: Guest requires legitimacy verification before travel commitment.

new_discoveries.relates_to_competitor: This extends the Roomster-like trust pattern upstream: before profile evaluation, users must first verify that the channel itself is real, which adds friction before normal marketplace decisions even begin.
new_discoveries.framework_analysis: Play Bigger Ch.1-2 implies category leaders define and own the core risk narrative. When legitimacy proof is improvised (LinkedIn links, ad-hoc calls, manual reassurance), the company is not perceived as category authority; users stay in defensive verification mode.

new_discoveries.title: Availability Opacity From Cross-Platform Calendars Creates Failed Reschedules

transcript_evidence.speaker: host
transcript_evidence.quote: Airbnb. I have some of them today.
transcript_evidence.context: Host inventory is managed across multiple platforms.

transcript_evidence.speaker: host
transcript_evidence.quote: you guys have the most up to date. We can update that.
transcript_evidence.context: Availability requires manual synchronization and intervention.

transcript_evidence.speaker: host
transcript_evidence.quote: there can be some difficulties there in matching with your listing availability
transcript_evidence.context: Mismatch between desired usage and actual availability becomes a repeated coordination burden.

new_discoveries.relates_to_competitor: Like Roomster's search-confidence gap, users are shown possibility before certainty; they spend effort on dates that may fail due to hidden constraints.
new_discoveries.framework_analysis: Under Play Bigger's 'category as organizing principle,' availability should be a first-order truth in the experience. If users must coordinate through screenshots and manual updates, the platform behaves like a lead router, not a category-defining system.

library_connections.connection: The Trust Credential Stack directly addresses scam anxiety by sequencing verification mechanisms before trust claims.
Pre-Packaged Proposal reduces ad-hoc negotiation load, but current transcript evidence shows rescheduling/payment commitments still spill into manual text/call channels.
Matching platform interaction speed to conversational speed helps replace fragmented text threads with clear, structured actions.
Current-Week Hero Card improves active-stay clarity for recurring actions, but host-side operational accountability artifacts remain mostly outside product rails.
Agent Continuity Frame supports early legitimacy transfer by making communication feel person-backed rather than anonymous-platform originated.
Surface Real-Time Availability Inside the Guest's Decision Flow is a direct solution path for the Airbnb-sync opacity described in the calls.
